Description: ConnectiCare agreed to pay $200,000 in restitution and $30,000 to the state in settlement of allegations it violated state law by failing to provide notice to those affected that their group health plan was terminated due to the non-payment of employer premiums.

The New York Attorney announced agreements with six health maintenance organizations that would empower consumers to challenge denials of coverage. The HMOs also agreed to pay a total of $1 million to the state AG's office to cover the cost of the investigation. The announcement did not specify how that cost would be divided among the six plans. Here we assume it was split equally.
GHI agreed to reimburse consumers who were required to pay up to $2,000 for services that were supposed to be fully covered by insurance.

Company: Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York (HIP)

New York State authorities ordered 11 insurance companies to refund a total of $114.5 million to holders of policies that covered 573,748 people who were overcharged for health insurance premiums in 2010.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: The Department of Financial Services fined a group of insurance companies a total of $2.7 million for failing to notify small businesses that they were eligible to buy special insurance coverage for mental illnesses and children with serious emotional disturbances.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Notes: Company is plan administrator. Penalty amount reported in range of $10,001 to $50,000.
